threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects TOKEN OBFUSCATION technique from Invoke-Obfuscation
Detects suspicious PowerShell invocation with a parameter substring
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Daniel Bohannon (idea), Roberto Rodriguez (Fix)

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=1B3B40FBC889FD4C645CC12C85D0805AC36BA254,MD5=95000560239032BC68B4C2FDFCDEF913,SHA256=D3F8FADE829D2B7BD596C4504A6DAE5C034E789B6A3DEFBE013BDA7D14466677,IMPHASH=741776AACCFC5B71FF59832DCDCACE0F; CurrentDirectory=c:\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\wbem\wmiprvse.exe; CommandLine=powershell.exe -exec Bypass -c iex([System.Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetString([System.Convert]::FromBase64String((get-content C:\\ProgramData\\WindowsDefender.ini)))); FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wbem\WmiPrvSE.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects registry changes to Microsoft Office "AccessVBOM" to a value of "1" which disables trust access for VBA on the victim machine and lets attackers execute malicious macros without any Microsoft Office warnings.
Detects changes to Microsoft Office protected view registry keys with which the attacker disables this feature.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: DLL Loaded From Suspicious Location Via Cmspt.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects cmstp loading "dll" or "ocx" files from suspicious locations
Detect commandline usage of Microsoft Connection Manager Profile Installer (cmstp.exe) to install specially formatted local .INF files
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: E.M. Anhaus (originally from Atomic Blue Detections, Endgame), oscd.community

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=84AA48946D4F9A9DFE4C1AF6F96C44B643229A73,MD5=2A9828E0C405422D166E0141054A04B3,SHA256=94152FB98573FE31C0CE49D260D760DD173741D663414DE718A37AAC7E8EF11F,IMPHASH=109BA8ED3C458360A74EA1216207CA09; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=CMSTP.EXE; Product=Microsoft(R) Connection Manager; Description=Microsoft Connection Manager Profile Installer; FileVersion=7.2.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\Explorer.EXE; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\cmstp.exe" /s c:\programdata\DefenderService.inf; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\explorer.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\System32\cmstp.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects registry changes to Microsoft Office "VBAWarning" to a value of "1" which enables the execution of all macros, whether signed or unsigned.
Detects usage of the "FromBase64String" function in the commandline which is used to decode a base64 encoded string

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects changing the PowerShell script execution policy to a potentially insecure level using the "-ExecutionPolicy" flag.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential WMI Lateral Movement WmiPrvSE Spawned PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects Powershell as a child of the WmiPrvSE process. Which could be a sign of lateral movement via WMI.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious DNS Query for IP Lookup Service APIs
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects DNS queries for IP lookup services such as "api.ipify.org" originating from a non browser process.
Detects modification of autostart extensibility point (ASEP) in registry.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Victor Sergeev, Daniil Yugoslavskiy, Gleb Sukhodolskiy, Timur Zinniatullin, oscd.community, Tim Shelton, frack113 (split)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects malicious document used by MuddyWater
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO External IP Lookup Domain (ipify .org) in DNS Lookup
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert dns $HOME_NET any -> any any (msg:"ET INFO External IP Lookup Domain (ipify .org) in DNS Lookup"; dns.query; dotprefix; content:".ipify.org"; nocase; endswith; classtype:misc-activity; sid:2047702; rev:1; metadata:affected_product Any, attack_target Client_and_Server, created_at 2023_08_22, deployment Perimeter, performance_impact Low, confidence High, signature_severity Informational, tag External_IP_Lookup, updated_at 2023_08_22, reviewed_at 2023_10_06;)

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The macro begins by defining and executing the `Document_Open()` and `TextBox1_GotFocus()` subroutines. Both subroutines employ similar obfuscation techniques and exhibit identical behaviors. They start by calling the `FUbx()` function with Base64-encoded strings, obtained from `kHus()`, `yjcD()`, and `CjQd()`. The `FUbx()` function uses a combination of `ztwU()`, `xmRJ()`, and `SCcV()` to decode the Base64 strings. These functions perform bitwise XOR operations, character conversion based on ASCII codes, and string concatenation, respectively. The `ztwU()` function takes two integers as input, performs bitwise XOR, and returns the result.  The `xmRJ()` converts an integer into a character using the `Chr()` function. The `SCcV()` function simply concatenates two strings.

The decoded Base64 strings represent a JavaScript code, an XML package containing JavaScript code, and configuration data for persistence, respectively. The subroutines then utilize the `YoDE()` function to write the decoded Base64 strings to three different files.  The `YoDE()` function creates a text file at the specified path using `CreateTextFile` and writes the content from the second argument into it. The file paths are obfuscated by the `xmRJ()` and `SCcV()` functions and point to locations under the user's profile directory.

The subroutines conclude by calling the `kljZ()` function. The `kljZ()` function creates a WMI object using `GetObject` to interact with the Windows registry. It then constructs a registry key path using the `xmRJ` and `SCcV` functions to point to a Run entry in the user's registry hive. Finally, the function sets a new value in the aforementioned Run entry, the value being the result of the `FUbx` function called with the `bmjj` argument.  The `bmjj` function returns a Base64-encoded string which, when decoded, translates to the command "cmd.exe /s c:\programdata\defender\service.inf". This suggests an intention to execute a file named "service.inf" located in the "c:\programdata\defender" directory using the command prompt with the `/s` flag, which modifies the treatment of string delimiters.  

This analysis suggests the macro is designed to drop and execute an executable file and establish persistence through a registry Run entry.
